node.statement: Conclusion and Uniformity: Combining Nodes 1.1-1.5, the integral equals c(Pi,pi) q^{-k(Pi,pi) s} where c(Pi,pi) != 0 is a product of the nonzero Gauss sum (Node 1.5) and the nonzero torus value of W^circ (Node 1.3), and k(Pi,pi) is an explicit integer depending on conductor exponents. This is a nonzero monomial, hence finite and nonzero for all s (Node 1.2). The choice W = W^circ depends only on Pi (Node 1.3); for each pi, the quantities Q, u_Q, V^circ change but the Gauss sum mechanism applies universally since conductor matching is built into the definition of Q. QED.
